column1: "After This, Therefore Because of This" Fallacy (Post Hoc, Ergo Propter Hoc)
column4: The "After This, Therefore Because of This" Fallacy is the assumption that event A caused event B merely because B occurred after A.
column7: For example: "My child became autistic right after she got her vaccine, so the vaccine must have caused it."
column11: To help a person overcome this fallacy, give counterexamples of people who experienced the first event but not the second. Show statistics about the percentage of times that the second event follows the first.

column4: The Actor-Observer Asymmetry occurs when people subconsciously attribute behavior to different causes depending on whether they're the person performing the behavior (the *actor*) or merely a witness (an *observer*). When assessing their own behavior as actors, people tend to emphasize the influence of the situation on their behavior and downplay the influence of their own personality or character. When assessing others' behavior as observers, the reverse is true: people's assessment of others' behavior tends to emphasize the influence of personality or character on the behavior and downplay the influence of the situation. See also: Fundamental Attribution Error.
column5: This has been demonstrated in studies by differentiating between actors' and observers' explanations in the following way: people's explanations were separated into theoretically meaningful distinctions (e.g., reasons vs. causal history of reason explanations). The responses were categorized, and the differences emerged.
column7: For example: "I haven't been able to get into the habit of going to the gym because life has just been so busy lately. Every day, I go to work, come home and spend a few minutes with my kids and spouse, cook dinner, and work on remodeling our back porch. I don't have time to go to the gym! But I'm totally unlike my spouse: they avoid the gym out of pure laziness."
column11: To overcome this bias, it might help to ask people to consider how a friend, loved one, or ideal person would have behaved in the same situation. For example, if a person skipped gym day because of a thunderstorm that day, ask them whether or not their gym buddy also missed that day because of the storm. By comparing their actions against other people in identical situations, they might see that the context was less relevant than they supposed and that their character was more relevant than they realized.

column4: An Ad Hoc Rescue is an attempt to save a cherished belief by repeatedly revising the argument in favor of it to explain away problems.
column7: For example: "I don't care if it gives me better cardiovascular health, better mental health, better sleep quality, and longer life expectancy---I still think that regular exercise would just be torture."
column8: rescue, revise, edit, erase, backtrack, goalpost, move
column11: It might help to show people facts. For example, if you'd like to encourage someone to start giving to a high-impact charity, but they keep coming up with new reasons why this would be useless or harmful, you could show them objective evidence regarding the charity's impact. Of course, this assumes that they share the same values as you but believe other strategies are more effective. If they don't share the same values, then your attempts to address Ad Hoc Rescue may not help.

column4: The Ad Hominem Fallacy occurs when a person attacks the arguer instead of the argument in order to conclude that the argument is false.
column7: For example: "That researcher is overweight! We can't trust their meta-analysis about the health impacts of saturated fat intake."
column11:
To overcome this bias, you could ask people to replace the actual messenger with a trusted imaginary messenger (or merely omit the messenger altogether); then, ask them to reconsider the message.

To leverage this bias, you could deliver the message using a messenger that you know the audience will trust. In such a case, it's still important to tell the audience that the claims are true for reasons other than that they're being delivered by a trusted messenger; the trusted messenger only acts as a sort of Trojan horse to deploy the message behind the defenses of the audience, not as proof of the message's veracity.

column1: Affirmative Conclusion from a Negative Premise Fallacy
column4: The Affirmative Conclusion from a Negative Premise Fallacy occurs when an affirmative conclusion is assumed to follow from two negative premises; for example: "A is not a subset of B. B is not a subset of C. Therefore, A is a subset of C."
column7:
For example: "We don't read that trash. People who read that trash don't appreciate real literature. Therefore, we appreciate real literature." 

Another example: "People who take smoke breaks at work aren't the type who can never relax. People who can't relax don't have a healthy work-life balance. So, people who take smoke breaks have a healthy work-life balance."
column11: To overcome this fallacy, draw Venn diagrams to illustrate the relationships of the categories involved to correct the logic of the faulty argument. (This is a useful strategy for many errors that occur when reasoning about categories.) Also, give empirical evidence that contradicts the faulty conclusion in order to update the person's beliefs (in case their reasoning is motivated by other factors).

column4: Affirming a Disjunct Fallacy is a logical fallacy made in deductive arguments in which it is falsely assumed that if one statement or category applies, then another cannot apply. This fallacy has the form: "A or B. A. Therefore, not B." If it is possible for both A and B to be true at the same time (i.e., if they're not mutually exclusive), then it is erroneous to conclude that one disjunct must be false merely because the other disjunct is true.
column7:
For example, someone might believe that either "you stop smoking socially at parties" *or* "you keep enjoying parties" without realizing that the two are not mutually exclusive categories. (In other words, they may not realize that it is possible to stop smoking socially at parties while still enjoying them.)

For example: "You can love America, or you can be a socialist."
column8: disjunct, affirm, either, or, inclusive, exclusive
column11: To overcome this fallacy, ask: "Is it possible for both disjuncts to be true at the same time?" For example: "Can a person quit drinking and still have fun?" Also, show examples where both disjuncts are true at the same time. In particular, it's important to show anecdotal evidence from the lives of loved ones when a person's reasoning is strongly motivated by emotion and/or identity, as in the cases of religion and politics. In other words, it's important not only to ask the question "Can a person hold belief X and still be a good person?" but also to show examples of real people, especially loved ones, who *do* hold belief X and who *are* still good people.

column4: This fallacy has the form: "If P, then Q. Q. Therefore P." The mistake lies in the assumption that if P implies Q, then Q implies P.
column7: For example: "Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit."
column8: after, consequent, imply, implication, if, then
column11: To overcome this fallacy, show that there are other ways to arrive at the current state of affairs by giving concrete counterexamples. In the example above ("Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit."), it's possible that Alice has gotten fit through some other means than Crossfit; perhaps she does P90X, for example.

column4: The Ambiguity Effect is a cognitive bias wherein decision-makers tend to select options for which the probability of a favorable outcome is known instead of an option for which the probability of a favorable outcome is unknown or ambiguous.
column7:
For example: "I know that if I pick Door #1, I have a 15% chance of winning a moderately good prize. I also know that if I pick Door #2, I'll win a prize, but I don't know how good the prize will be or what the chances of winning are. I guess I'll pick Door #1!"

Another example: "I want to invest in Company #1 because it has a proven track record of success...even though that investment will have a low ROI and I'm not absolutely in love with their product. I'd rather do that than invest in Company #2 because, even though Company #2 has a product I like, I just don't know anything about them!"

Another example: Someone might choose a fixed-rate mortgage (where the interest rate doesn't change) over a variable-rate mortgage (where the interest rate fluctuates with the market) even if the variable-rate mortgage saves them money.
column11: To overcome this effect, it might help to report the likelihood of all outcomes wherever possible. It might also help to develop an intuition for the probabilities by comparing them to commonly-known outcomes.

column4: The Anchoring Bias occurs when a person's expectation about one thing is affected by something they saw, heard, or thought before. In other words, it occurs when a person relies too heavily on a specific piece of information to govern their thought process.
column5: In one study, an audience was asked to write the last two digits of their social security number and consider whether they would pay this number of dollars for items such as wine, chocolate, and computer equipment, the values of which they did not know. They were then asked to bid for these items. The result was that the audience members with higher two-digit numbers would submit bids that were between 60% and 120% higher than those with the lower social security numbers. Put simply, the higher the (social security) number in mind, the higher the bid. The social security numbers had become their "anchors."
column6: Partly from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchoring_(cognitive_bias) but looks like it is already reworded somewhat
column7:
For example, when buying an expensive piece of software, the initial quote you get might anchor you to a particular price.

As another example, when negotiating a contract, the initial terms of the agreement might act as an anchor for the remainder of the negotiations. Wins might then be measured with respect to the original terms rather than in terms of absolute benefits or losses.
column11:
To overcome this bias, define one's expectations _before_ being exposed to potential anchors (e.g., prior to obtaining quotes, entering negotiations, and so on). It might also help to be reminded that one's memory of past experiences may be out-of-date or based on incorrect information. 

To leverage this bias, one could suggest a specific number (e.g., dollar amount) as a starting point for giving, negotiating, etc.
column18: On some tests, have a question that involves someone paying $15 for a hamburger and omit that question on other tests. On all tests, have a question asking how much money one considers to be "expensive" for a hamburger. See if the $15 mark has an anchoring effect.
column19: Idea for a within-subjects test: Ask 2 different gambling questions, one with an anchor and one without, where the test taker has to say how much he/she'd risk in a certain game for a certain probability of reward. The 2 games would have to be similar in that it would be irrational for a person to be more risk averse in one than another, but they'd have to be different in way that prevented the test taker from realizing this. Also must be careful that a subject's different answers don't result from the framing bias, rather than the anchoring bias.

column4: The Anecdotal Evidence Fallacy is the discounting of evidence arrived at by systematic search or testing in favor of a few firsthand stories.
column7: For example: "I'm going to carry on smoking. My grandfather smoked 40 cigarettes a day until he died at age 90."
column11:
To overcome this fallacy, point out that anecdotes can never be generalized to a population. A population represents many individuals, but a single individual does not necessarily represent the population. So it's possible to tell a true anecdote that's nevertheless statistically rare for a population.

To leverage this fallacy, use anecdotes to describe what individual experiences may look like. If you do this, be sure to mention that the anecdotes are only part of the statistical story. In other words, remind people that "your mileage may vary."

column4: The Appeal to Authority Fallacy is the argument that a statement is correct because it was made by a person or source that the audience regards as authoritative.
column7: For example: "As Samuel Johnson said, 'patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel.'"
column11:
To overcome this fallacy, it could help to analyze the message itself after disconnecting it from the messenger. For example, "I know you've adopted Diet X because Dr. Oz recommended it, but is it really true that X is safe and effective? I think you should see what the research shows about X before adopting it."

To leverage this fallacy, you could ask trusted authority figures to deliver messages. For example, "I'm Alex Trebec, and I want you to know how important it is to buy life insurance." In such a case, it's still important to tell the audience that the claims are true for reasons other than that they're being delivered by a trusted messenger; the trusted messenger only acts as a sort of Trojan horse to deploy the message behind the defenses of the audience, not as proof of the message's veracity.

column4: The Appeal to Common Practice Fallacy is the claim that something is true or acceptable because it's commonly practiced.
column7:
For example: "This bank has some problems with corruption. But there's nothing going on here that doesn't go on in all the other banks."

Another example: "This procedure is practiced at 90% of hospitals, so it's the best option we've got for our patient!"
column11: To overcome this fallacy, it could help to show counterexamples of times when a common practice or belief was later shown to be false, dangerous, or immoral. (This by itself doesn't prove that a claim is false; it only demonstrates that the majority isn't always right and that common practice isn't proof of truth or moral acceptability.) For example, owning slaves used to be a common practice around the world. The ubiquity of slavery, however, should not be taken as evidence that it was morally justifiable.

column4: The Appeal to Consequences Fallacy is an argument in which the validity of its premise (typically a belief) is judged based on whether the consequences of that premise lead to desirable or undesirable consequences. It typically has a form like: "If P, then bad consequences. Therefore, not P." Or: "If P, then good consequences. Therefore, P!"
column7:
For example: "Your theory cannot possibly be true because if it were, our lives would be meaningless."

Another example: "This new exercise plan is going to hurt like heck, so it's probably not good for me."

Another example: "The last time I tried to stop smoking, I had horrible withdrawal symptoms. So it's probably best for me to just keep smoking."
column11:
To overcome this fallacy, provide absurd, extreme, or humorous counterexamples to show that the truth of a proposition is not connected to its consequences. For example: "If there were serial killers, then lots of people would die horrible deaths! Therefore, serial killers must not exist." Or: "If everyone was perfectly kind to each other, then we'd have no more wars. Therefore, everyone must already be perfectly kind to each other!"

Directly pointing out this fallacy might have the potential to backfire. This kind of reasoning can be associated with cognitive dissonance and motivated reasoning, which may decrease the degree to which people can engage rationally and productively with information or arguments contradicting their current thinking (e.g. [Rothgerber, 2020](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0195666319306324?casa_token=TbOa-8zyVboAAAAA:pwCeOrthXBA3hSOV8dSmUNyL5cIT4oeSJV3jYRNd5wCSseAtLw4rvD0cYYRU6VZRhBohasvyO7Y)). 

Motivated reasoning may become particularly problematic when the topic at hand is framed in moral terms (since topics framed in terms of morality can be associated with more polarization than those perceived through a pragmatic lens; [Abeywickrama et al., 2020](https://jspp.psychopen.eu/index.php/jspp/article/view/5263)). 

With these caveats in mind, given the right circumstances and the right person, it might sometimes be worth telling someone when it seems like this fallacy is affecting their reasoning (if the backfire risk appears to be sufficiently low). 

This may be worth taking into consideration when raising initial awareness of a given behavior or its consequences: if the target audience has certain ideas that they hold strongly and value highly, then it could backfire to convey information that directly challenges those beliefs. And when information _is_ presented that _could_ contradict someone's cherished beliefs, it might be preferable to share the information on its own---without sharing the conclusions or providing behavioral prescriptions---in order to encourage the person to come to their _own_ conclusions (for more information on this point, see the Generation Effect). 

Over the longer-term, it may help to encourage people to foster more epistemic humility, potentially through practicing dialogic argumentation in a wide variety of contexts ([Kuhn & Crowell, 2011](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0956797611402512?casa_token=j8n-fvNZXIcAAAAA%3ARQxwCnHBeC4V_rEOge0_-zqCBENDDml05g1n502cs7OTa8ADJ2pONhY88bhP2p3CHRm0C7RA6-lsww)). More research in this area is needed, but some evidence suggests that such approaches may enable people to become less attached to their desired conclusions ([Švaříček, 2019](https://www.phil.muni.cz/journals/index.php/studia-paedagogica/article/view/2063), which may increase their ability to form more realistic beliefs through the use of reasoning and evidence.

column4: The Appeal to Fear Fallacy is the argument that one of two things must be true and that, because one of the things is frightening, the other must be true. It usually has the form: "Either P or Q is true. Q is frightening. Therefore, P."
column7: For example, someone might be experiencing symptoms consistent with a diagnosis of Panic Disorder. They might believe: "Either these symptoms represent panic attacks, or I'm just experiencing normal sensations that everyone feels. But having a Panic Disorder diagnosis sounds frightening to me. Therefore, I'm just experiencing normal sensations that everyone feels."
column11:
To leverage this fallacy, highlight undesirable or risky outcomes that would result from failure to engage in a desired behavior change. It could also help to motivate people to maintain the behavior in cases where they either fear failure itself or fear the consequences of that failure. 

To overcome this fallacy, consider how severe the person's fear is and how strongly they hold their current beliefs relating to the feared outcome(s). Then, if it seems safe to do so, it might help to encourage the person to acknowledge the fear, analyze the reasons behind it, evaluate whether the fear is justified, and manage it directly. On the other hand, if the person has strongly-held beliefs relating to the fear or its consequences, it may be preferable to seek professional support. In the meantime, the strategies for the Appeal to Consequences Fallacy may also be worth considering.

column4: The Appeal to Flattery Fallacy is the use of an irrelevant compliment to slip in an unfounded claim; the audience might then accept the statement along with the flattery. It usually has the form: "You have desirable property X, so of course you'll know that P is true."
column7: For example: "Intelligent and sophisticated readers will of course recognize a fallacy like this when they read one."
column11: To overcome this fallacy, recognize it and/or point it out. It may also help to re-evaluate any claims based on the evidence supporting them, rather than other factors (such as accompanying flattery). Those trying to support others in their behavior change efforts should also avoid giving unwarranted or falsely-inflated flattery. (As well as being dishonest / unethical, this would also run the risk of backfiring via the Argument from Fallacy.)

column4: The Appeal to Hypocrisy Fallacy is the argument that a position is wrong because the person arguing for it does not live in accordance with it.
column7:
For example: "He says lying is wrong. But look at him! He's been known to lie himself!"

Another example: "The big oil companies tell us that we as individuals should do more to prevent climate change by reducing, reusing, and recycling. But they're contributing to climate change on a massive scale, so we can't trust anything they say! So it's probably a waste of time and energy for us to reduce, reuse, and recycle."
column11: To overcome this fallacy, you should ideally adopt the behavior in question (or give a costly signal that you intend to adopt it) before encouraging others to do so. In cases where other people are providing behavioral advice or tips, it may be advisable for the person explaining it to be selected based on their own experience in engaging in the behavior in question so that their advice is (at least perceived to be) more credible.

column4: The Appeal to Incredulity Fallacy is the dismissal of a proposition as false because it sounds unbelievable.
column7:
For example, someone might think it is unbelievable that there is a free activity that can increase their lifespan, improve their physical and mental health, and improve their cognitive abilities. (But getting enough sleep each night is a free activity that does all of these things.)

Another example: "You're telling me that humans and chimpanzees shared a common ancestor? That's absurd! Humans are completely different from chimps!"
column11: To overcome this fallacy, share any available evidence so that people can draw their own conclusions regarding the claim(s) they are doubting. It may also help to show them that a person they respect believes the claim(s).

column4: The Appeal to Money Fallacy can occur with respect either to people or to things. When it concerns people, the fallacy is the belief that the more money a person has, the wiser or more knowledgeable they are. When it concerns things, the fallacy is the belief that the more something costs, the more valuable it must be.
column7:
For example: "This product costs more, so it must be better."

Another example: "He's the richest man in the world! He must be doing something right!"
column11:
To overcome this fallacy, try challenging it directly by asking questions. For example: "Is it really true that this product is better than its competitors simply because it's the most expensive?"

To leverage this fallacy, place a relatively high price on the relevant training, equipment, or other materials required to engage in the behavior.

column4: The Appeal to Motive Fallacy is the claim an argument must be false because the person making it has biased or ulterior motives.
column7: For example: "We can't trust the evidence that he produces because he'll sell millions of copies of his book if people believe that his theories are true."
column11: To overcome this fallacy, avoid allowing people with relevant conflicts of interest to be the ones promoting behavior change. For example, if someone owns a high-protein product company, they should not be the person chosen to run a nutrition workshop.

column4: The Appeal to Nature Fallacy is the claim that natural things are automatically good and that synthetic things are automatically bad.
column7:
For example: "Vaccines are unnatural. Therefore, they are bad for me."

Another example: "Why would people make genetically-modified foods? Natural foods are already perfect!"
column11:
To overcome this fallacy, provide counterexamples. If a beneficial behavior is seen as unnatural, provide evidence that it results in positive outcomes. If a detrimental behavior is seen as natural, provide evidence that it results in negative outcomes.

In some cases, this fallacy may be deeply connected to a person's worldview. If a person views humans as being a fundamentally different kind of thing than animals, then man-made things will take on a particularly significant quality that they would otherwise not have if the person were to view humans as merely being another kind of animal. For example, are skyscrapers "natural"? If one views humans as just another kind of animal, then comparing skyscrapers to anthills might seem appropriate; but to a person who views humans as being metaphysically different than animals, such a comparison might seem degrading to humans or even simply absurd. In other words, if a person is a materialist who believes that nature is just "everything that is," then skyscrapers and vaccines and sodas are just as "natural" as anthills and venom and honey. But a person who believes that humans are separate from nature will probably view man-made things with some amount of mistrust. And, of course, challenging a person's worldview is extremely difficult and likely to backfire. Offering counterexamples may still be the best course of action, but be aware that they may not be received warmly.

This fallacy may also represent a response to the facts that (1) we don't always test our inventions sufficiently well and (2) we are often motivated by profit to invent quickly. We've noticed that we have, in the past, rushed to invent products that later caused lots of damage, and that's made us skeptical about the benefits of new inventions. The concern that inventions be well-tested is valid and extremely important, but it's also separate from whether or not human inventions are "natural."

column4: The Appeal to Novelty Fallacy is the belief that something is automatically better because it is new or newer.
column7: For example: "The latest version of this operating system is going to make my computer faster and better."
column11:
To overcome this fallacy, it could help to point out that there are significant (but often less noticeable) risks and costs associated with always having/using the newest thing. For example, adopting the latest fad diet may put one's health at risk (since there may be little research into the long-term effects of the diet). It might also help to point out that old things may more reliable, well-tested, and cheaper.

To leverage this fallacy, one could show that the target behavior can be adopted in a new way. For example, to convince people to stop smoking cigarettes (which is not a new idea), one could show them new techniques and tools for quitting, such as a new medication or a new kind of chewing gum.

column4: The Appeal to Pity Fallacy is the attempt to induce pity to sway opponents.
column7: For example, someone might want to encourage their friend to stop chain-smoking but might also think that their friend has been under a lot of stress for the past few years. If they engage in the Appeal to Pity Fallacy, they might prematurely conclude that now wouldn't be the time to tell them about a new quitting aid on the market.
column11: To overcome this fallacy, provide or ask for an outside perspective. Remind people that you do care for them, and that it's your care for them that's spurring your encouragement of their behavior change. In a behavior change context, the Appeal to Pity Fallacy can represent an abuse and manipulation of one person's natural affection and care for another. For example, Alice might say to Bob, "Making me change my behavior would hurt, and you don't want to hurt me, do you?" But Bob should remind Alice his care and affection for her is exactly what's motivating him to encourage her to change her behavior.

column4: The Appeal to Popular Belief Fallacy is the claim that something is true because the majority of people believe it.
column7: For example: "Everyone knows that milk is essential for healthier bones."
column11: To overcome this fallacy, point out evidence and counterexamples to demonstrate that the claim in question isn't true.

column4: The Appeal to Probability Fallacy is the assumption that because something *could* happen, then it *will* happen.
column7:
For example: "There are many hackers that spread worms through the internet. Therefore, if you use the internet without a firewall, it is inevitable that you will be hacked sooner or later."

Another example: "A few people have had adverse reactions to the vaccine, so I don't want to get vaccinated because I just know I'll have an adverse reaction too!"
column11:
To overcome this fallacy, describe concrete examples with similar probabilities. For example, "I know you're afraid of the negative side effects of starting your new habit, but they're about as likely as being attacked by a giant squid." Sometimes, exaggerating the person's own inference (from some probability to 100% probability) in a friendly way with humor and mild sarcasm can show them how absurd the inference is. For example, "Oh, you're afraid of having a heart attack when you exercise? You're right; that's a valid fear. Most 25-year-olds I've known have died of heart attacks while exercising, which is why there's so few of them left. It's also why doctors recommend never exercising if you're over 10 years old." Or: "All startups succeed! None have ever failed. Yours is totally going to succeed too!"

Encourage the person to seek professional help if the faulty reasoning is overlapping with [all-or-nothing thinking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_distortion#All-or-nothing_thinking) and/or with [catastrophizing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exaggeration#Cognitive_distortions), and use similar strategies to address it. To overcome this fallacy over the longer-term, it might also be beneficial to encourage the person to practice thinking more probabilistically to reduce their tendency to engage in this fallacy in the first place.

column4: The Appeal to Ridicule Fallacy is casting an opponent's argument in a light that makes it sound silly or ridiculous in order to bolster a claim that it is false.
column7: For example: "If Einstein's theory of relativity is right, that would mean that when I drive my car, it gets shorter and more massive the faster I go. That's crazy!"
column11: To overcome this fallacy, ask the person to consider whether they'd come to the same conclusion given the same evidence. It might also be possible to reduce the probability of this fallacy arising if the people and organizations presenting information about a given behavior are respected, credible, or otherwise less susceptible to ridicule.

column4: The Appeal to Spite Fallacy is the dismissal of a claim by appealing to a personal bias against the claimant.
column7: For example: "Don't you just hate how those rich Liberal Hollywood actors go on TV to promote their agendas?"
column11: To overcome this fallacy, it might help to point it out and encourage the person to focus on the information itself rather than the people or organization(s) conveying it. Ask someone the audience trusts to argue the case for the behavior change.

column4: The Appeal to Tradition Fallacy is the claim that something is true because it has (apparently) always been that way. (See also: Status Quo Bias.)
column7: For example: "Marriage is the union between man and women. It has always been that way, and always should be that way. Therefore gay marriage is wrong."
column11:
To overcome or avoid this fallacy, introduce behavior change interventions with small and incremental steps to reduce the resistance associated with breaking from tradition. Show examples, especially of a person's loved ones, who have changed their behavior and who are still "good" people, even though they've apparently abandoned tradition.

To leverage this fallacy, point out cases where someone is already engaging in a behavior long enough for them to perceive it as a tradition (in which case the Appeal to Tradition Fallacy may help them to stick to it). Also, point out ways in which the new, positive behavior aligns with a person's traditions and values.

column4: The Appeal to Wishful Thinking Fallacy is the belief that a claim is true or false just because they strongly hope it is.
column7:
For example: "The President wouldn't lie. He's our leader and a good American."

As another example, someone may desire (and thus believe) that there will be no expected negative health impacts from smoking.
column11: To overcome Wishful Thinking that relates to strongly-held beliefs, it might help to use similar strategies as those suggested for the Appeal to Consequences Fallacy. For hopes which are less strongly held, or in situations where the backfire risk is deemed to be sufficiently low, it may help to point out when Wishful Thinking is occurring or to provide evidence to enable the person to draw their own conclusions.

column4: The Argument from Fallacy Fallacy (sometimes just called the "Fallacy Fallacy") is the argument that, because an embedded argument contains a flaw, its conclusion must be false. It usually has the following form (where P is an embedded argument): "If P is sound or strong, then P's conclusion is true. P is unsound or not strong. Therefore, P's conclusion is false."
column7:
For example: "My opponent has just argued that the earth is round because he desperately hopes it is. He is engaging in wishful thinking (i.e., assuming that a claim is true because one wants it to be true), so his conclusion that the earth is round must be false."

Another example: "Our opponents have falsely argued that abortion should be legal because it reduces crime rates. Now that this claim has been proven false, we can conclude that abortion should be made illegal."
column11:
To overcome the Argument from Fallacy, encourage the person to "steelman" the argument (i.e., to build the strongest possible version of their opponent's argument and then see if they can defeat it) or to focus on the information itself rather than on the fallacious ways in which it is currently being conveyed. 

It might also be possible to reduce the probability of this fallacy arising in the first place if care is taken not to promote a positive behavior (or discourage a negative one) in a way that employs fallacies.

column4: The Argument from Ignorance Fallacy is the assertion that a proposition is necessarily true because it has not been proven false (or vice versa).
column7:
For example: "We know that quantum mechanics is a true theory because every attempt to test it has failed to find evidence against the theory."

Another example: "You can't prove that unicorns *don't* exist; therefore, they *do* exist!"
column11: To overcome this fallacy, draw on concrete examples of statements that the person already believes could be false despite the fact that the belief has not been explicitly proven false. If they hold their beliefs strongly, then similar strategies might be useful as those for Wishful Thinking and the Appeal to Consequences Fallacy. In cases where the backfire risk is deemed to be sufficiently low, it may be worth encouraging the person to practice actively considering the reasons that arguments in opposition to their own could actually turn out to be true. An example of this could be trying to find the best ways of supporting an opposing argument, which can be called "steel-manning" the argument ([Mattes, 2020](https://search.informit.com.au/fullText;dn=077923104428244;res=IELENG)).

To overcome this tendency in the longer-term, it might help to practice activey considering (rather than dismissing) alternative points of view. This can foster epistemic/intellectual humility, which might be useful for addressing many of the other cognitive biases in this list. In addition to increasing the degree to which people engage with alternative points of view, intellectual humility has been associated with rising to challenges, and persisting after setbacks ([Porter et al. 2020](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1041608020300686?casa_token=sJNl4ThLbWUAAAAA:E8U8KRkr11qvyWjYzRoIIiR8SaC_J2L9rML1N-a1qBt0CgNVIEPjWli410B7hb0ONUG7HtQ8x-8)), which could be useful for behavior change.

column4: The Typical Mind Fallacy is the fallacious assumption that one's own mind is "typical" and that other minds in the general population are therefore similar to one's own.
column5: There was a debate, in the late 1800s, about whether "imagination" was simply a turn of phrase or a real phenomenon. That is, can people actually create images in their minds which they see vividly, or do they simply say "I saw it in my mind" as a metaphor for considering what it looked like? The debate was resolved by Francis Galton, who gave people some very detailed surveys, and found that some people did have mental imagery, while others did not. The ones who did simply assumed everyone did, and the ones who didn't simply assumed everyone didn't, to the point of coming up with absurd justifications for why they were lying or misunderstanding the question. There was a wide spectrum of imaging ability, from about five percent of people with perfect eidetic imagery to three percent of people completely unable to form mental images.

column4: Zero-risk Bias refers to the cognitive bias favoring opportunities to eliminate rather than mitigate risk. This can become relevant when there are multiple possible courses of action, some of which involve complete elimination of a subcategory of risk and others of which do not. This bias can cause people to irrationally favor options that completely eliminate a subcategory of risk, even if other options come with a greater absolute reduction in risk overall.
column5: This bias has been demonstrated in multiple studies, with its probability of affecting decision-making appearing to depend on the decision-making context and framing (e.g., [Schneider et al., 2017](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2017-30652-004?casa_token=DoeNW5Pr_h4AAAAA:x2ARETOKfbu36oNRrcd8dgznUGeHhOi5y-XfpqkBuHZ6Ijq7OZy0sUZsk_onyEH3B1idwdM36R9yEdr8XN81p_6F); [Raue & Schneider, 2019](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-11456-5_5)). In one recent study ([Cantarelli, Belle & Belardinelli, 2020](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0734371X18778090?casa_token=SuOajn6vVvgAAAAA%3A-f8cxnU1B4lplrwGne2UrBwLTS6UVgwcmN1kd3J6UimijTGMaq-ZvuzOcmlwIda0g7QXQiw4KPUhuA)), 495 nurses were given a scenario where they were told that an infectious disease had broken out in two developing countries, and that the doses of the perfectly effective vaccination were limited. One intervention plan would save an expected 6,000 lives via partial vaccination coverage in both nations: this plan would reduce deaths from 8,000 to 4,000 in one country and from 4,000 to 2,000 in the other country. The other intervention plan would save an expected 5,000 lives, but entailed a full vaccination coverage in one nation (from 4,000 to 0 deaths, so zero risk of death from that disease in that country) and a partial vaccination coverage in the other nation (from 8,000 to 7,000 in that country). Approximately 29% of the sample appeared to be affected by zero-risk bias, favoring the scenario that involved complete elimination of risk in one of the countries, despite that option saving 1,000 fewer lives overall.

column4: Overestimating one's desirable qualities, and underestimating undesirable qualities, relative to other people. (Also known as "Lake Wobegon Effect," "Better-than-average Effect," or "Superiority Bias").
column5: In Kruger and Dunning's experiments, participants were given specific tasks (such as logic problems, grammar, and determining whether or not jokes were funny), and were asked to evaluate their performance on these tasks relative to the rest of the group, enabling a direct comparison of their actual and perceived performance. Results were divided into four groups, depending on actual performance. It was found that all four groups evaluated their performance as above average, meaning that the lowest-scoring group (the bottom 25%) showed a very large Illusory Superiority Bias. The researchers attributed this to the fact that the individuals who were worst at performing the tasks were also worst at recognizing skill in those tasks. This was supported by the fact that, given training, the worst subjects improved their estimate of their rank as well as getting better at the tasks.
